data.text: Contents
Introduction
The hearing screen is offered to all eligible babies shortly after birth using national screening protocols.

Newborn Hearing Screening Programme NHSP aims to identify permanent moderate, severe and profound hearing loss in newborn babies. Approximately 1:1000 babies born in the UK will have a permanent childhood hearing impairment that can significantly affect their language and social development. Early identification gives babies a better chance of developing speech and language skills and of making the most of social and emotional interaction at an early age. It enables practical and emotional support to be given to parents.
Scope
The purpose of this policy is to ensure there is a consistent and equitable approach to provision and monitoring of the Newborn Hearing Screening Programme across the Trust.
The aim of the newborn hearing screening is to:

Offer screening to all eligible babies >34 weeks gestation and up to 3 months of age who do not fulfil the criteria for direct referral to audiology. Eligibility is determined by NHSP protocols. available at
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing-screening- programme-nhsp-operational-guidance/1-introduction-and-contacts

To screen all babies within 4 weeks of birth or by  weeks gestation. To provide timely referral to audiology services as per national protocol, immediate referral if required within 2-4 weeks of screening and targeted referral if required at 7-9 months corrected gestation.
Provide all screening and paediatric audiology services in seamless family friendly manner and environment.
Definitions
PCHI  Permanent Childhood Hearing Impairment
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
NHSP Team Leader
Existing senior post holder in audiology or paediatrics responsible for being the champion of and strategic lead for the programme. Responsible for quality and governance.
Local Manager

Operational lead and responsible for day to day management of all aspects of  screening service including timely and appropriate  referral to audiology. Acts as  professional lead for local service, ensures protocols are adhered to and that key  performance indicators and standards are met. Leads the screening team and manages their training, activity and reviews.
Communication with multi-disciplinary team and liaison with other sites and Health Visitors to ensure all babies are offered a screen
Ensuring equipment is serviced and calibrated as required, QA checks are undertaken  and that equipment is safely stored

Local Screening Manager accountable to Commissioner for service delivery against the service specification by attending or providing information for local and regional Antenatal and Newborn Screening Boards.
Screeners

Undertake hearing screening for newborn babies under supervision of Local manager. Gathering and accurate recording of clinical and test data relevant to screening process, direct handling of newborn babies and contact with parents both as inpatients and once discharged to arrange outpatient appointments.
Paediatric Audiologists
Provide audiological assessment for babies referred from the screen either for immediate assessment or targeted review.
Service model
MSE operates a Hospital based screening service under the definition outlined by national NHSP operating procedures.
5.1.1 Well babies

Screening will be undertaken by NHSP trained staff ideally prior to the babies discharge from hospital. If the initial screening cannot be completed as an inpatient or the baby is delivered at home, an outpatient appointment will be arranged with the parent so that the screen can be completed within 4 weeks.
If no clear response is obtained on completion of the screen the baby will be referred to audiology services and an appointment made within 4 weeks.
5.1.2 Neonatal Intensive Care babies (NICU)

Any baby who is in NICU for >48 hours will be screened as NICU protocol. Screening will be carried out by NHSP trained screeners when the baby is well and close to discharge and aged >34 weeks gestation. All NICU babies should have their screen completed prior to discharge but if this does not occur an outpatient appointment will be arranged with the parent to complete the screen within 4 weeks.
5.1.3 If no clear response is obtained on completion of the screen the baby will be referred to audiology and an appointment made within 4 weeks.
5.1.4 The Newborn Hearing Screening service is offered to all babies born within MSE Trust that are eligible for screening
5.1.5 All babies not eligible for screening (as per NHSP protocols) will be referred immediately to audiology for assessment within 4 weeks.

5.1.6 All babies born at MSE hospitals who have a hospital outside the area as their responsible site will be offered a hearing screen prior to discharge and if a further appointment is required to complete the screen discussion will be with parents as to where this is performed
Workflow

All babies born under the responsibility of individual sites will have the data put onto Smart4Hearing(S4H) NHSP Screening Management system database via the NHS spine once NHS number has been issued.

Local failsafes are used to ensure that all babies born appear on S4H in a timely manner and that all babies born under the responsibility of the individual site are accounted for (Refer to appendix 2)

Verbal consent from the baby's mother following explanation of the screen should be obtained and babies should have their screen started by the screening team before being discharged from the birth hospital as per NHSP protocols
Follow up appointments are offered to ensure completion of the screen within 4 weeks for all those babies where screening was not completed prior to discharge or were born at home.

Babies who move in to area or who transfer in from tertiary centres between birth  and 3 months of age who have not been screened will be offered a hearing screen  by the local team. The responsibility for identifying these babies lies with Local Manager of the screening team, Health Visitor and local Child Health Department

If any family does not attend the agreed appointment, they will be offered a further appointment to complete the screen. If they do not attend at this time the baby will be discharged from the screening programme. The mother is written to stating that she can request a hearing screen until the baby is 3 months old and Child Health are informed (Refer to appendix 3)
Individual birth sites use local processes to ensure that outpatient clinics are booked

Babies referred immediately to audiology for unilateral or bilateral no clear response on the screen will have cCMV saliva swab taken at screening appointment to enable early diagnosis of potential cCMV infection .This follows site specific processes (see attached).Please refer to the Diagnosis and Management of Congenital Cytomegalovirus infection (CCMV) in babies who fail their Newborn hearing screen ( Broomfield Hospital see Appendix C) Saliva Swab for congenital Cytomeglalovirus– Southend Hospital ( see Appendix A) and cCMV Paediatric Pathway in BTUH.- Basildon Hospital ( see Appendix B)
Individual sites use local processes to ensure that audiology appointments are booked for both immediate and targeted referrals
Equipment
Equipment must meet the specifications as agreed by National Programme Centre.
Equipment must be used, maintained and calibrated as per National Programme
Centre NHSP Equipment Protocols. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing-screening- programme-nhsp-operational-guidance/5-equipment
Appropriate consumables must be available to enable continuous operation.
Current versions of software must be installed on equipment and IT systems to allow upload of screening data.
Training requirements

All screeners are required to have completed training and competency assessments in line with national procedures and protocols. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing-screening- programme-nhsp-operational-guidance/2-education-and-training

All staff are required to have annual competencies assessed and to complete NHSP e-learning annually with new starters, once deemed competent having passed ECA, to complete the Health Service Diploma.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Maternity and Gynaecology Policy Working Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References
https://www.gov.uk/topic/population-screening-programmes/newborn-hearing

Gov.uk Newborn hearing screening programme ( NHSP) operational guidance. Nov 2016 ( updated Sept 2021) available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/newborn-hearing-screening- programme-nhsp-operational-guidance
Appendix A: Saliva swab for congenital CMV (reference number: SOPN075; Southend Hospital site)
Click here to download the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP)
Appendix B: cCMV paediatric pathway for Basildon Hospital
Audiology notifies NICU consultant on service on extension 7343 of positive result
NICU consultant on service arranges urgent review of the patient in PAU (within hours 9-5pm)
In PAU:
Clinical review*
Blood tests (FBC, U&E, LFTs, CMV PCR)
Urgent referral to ophthalmology
Request urgent Cranial USS and MRI head
Liaise with audiology to organize urgent ABR
Complete BTUH cCMV proforma (Appendix 1)
Aim to complete investigations by  days old  (within hours 9-5pm)
If baby asymptomatic and all investigations negative: No treatment needed
If baby symptomatic and/or any of above investigations positive: Discuss with paediatric Infectious Diseases team at GOSH regarding treatment and ongoing management
If indicated, Offer treatment*  (by  days old):
Oral Valganciclovir 16mg/kg/dose twice daily.
IV ganciclovir should be used in babies unable to tolerate oral drug or in cases of uncertain gastrointestinal absorption.
Complete 6 months of antiviral treatment.
Follow up/ Monitoring*
Responsible consultant is the NICU consultant on service at the start of this pathway
* For further details/clarification, please refer to cCMV EoE guideline, available on the hub

Appendix 2 Appendix D:
MSE Newborn Hearing Screening Daily Workflow & Failsafes
Check all new proformas against post natal bed state

Print list of all previous day's deliveries from S4H, check against delivery register to ensure all babies have uploaded to S4H Locate any babies not on post natal unit so are aware of any discharged directly from CDS
Check status of all babies on NICU for potential discharge & admissions to paediatric unit who may require screen
Check which babies are receiving treatment
Clean equipment & perform equipment checks
Screen all eligible babies as per NHSP protocols
Periodically throughout day check for new deliveries which may be suitable for screening
Telephone or letter contact to mother's of babies discharged prior to screening or born at home on day 3 to explain screening & offering a screen appointment. Confirm in writing.
On completion of daily screening, upload results, ensure all correct & ratify.   Make & confirm any necessary follow up appointments.
Confirm attendance at clinic on local system.
